To rename a word consistently across an entire file in Vim, you can use the following command:

```
:%s/oldword/newword/g
```

Here's a breakdown of this command:

- `:%s` - This tells Vim to perform a substitution (`:s`) across all lines in the file (`%`)
- `/oldword/newword/` - This specifies the old word to replace and the new word to replace it with
- `g` - This flag tells Vim to replace all occurrences on each line, not just the first one

If you want to confirm each replacement, you can add the `c` flag:

```
:%s/oldword/newword/gc
```

This will prompt you for confirmation before each replacement.

If you want to match whole words only (to avoid replacing parts of larger words), you can use word boundaries:

```
:%s/\<oldword\>/newword/g
```

The `\<` and `\>` represent word boundaries.

Remember to replace "oldword" with the word you want to replace, and "newword" with its replacement.
